pyinterpolate.variogram.utils.exceptions module#

Additional exceptions and warnings for the variogram module.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moliński | @SimonMolinsky

exception AttributeSetToFalseWarning(validated)[source]#

Bases: Warning

Warning invoked when ExperimentalVariogram class attributes are set to False (is_semivariance, is_covariance, is_variance) but user wants to plot one of the indices controlled by those attributes (semivariance, covariance, variance) with a plot() method of this class.

exception MetricsTypeSelectionError[source]#

Bases: Exception

Error invoked if user doesn’t select any error type for the theoretical variogram modeling.

Variables:

message (str) –

exception UndefinedSMAPEWarning(message)[source]#

Bases: Warning

Warning invoked by the scenario when predicted value is equal to 0 and observation is equal to 0. It leads to

the 0/0 division and, in return, to NaN value at a specific position. Finally, user gets NaN as the output.

Parameters:

message (str)

Variables:

message (str) –

exception VariogramModelNotSetError[source]#

Bases: Exception

Exception raised when TheoreticalVariogram model name has not been set. (Model without name probably wasn’t fitted).

pyinterpolate.variogram.utils.metrics module#

Error metrics for the variogram model autofit.

Authors#

  1. Szymon Moliński | @SimonMolinsky

forecast_bias(predicted_array: array, real_array: array) → float[source]#

Function calculates forecast bias of prediction.

predicted_arraynumpy array

Array with predicted values.

real_arraynumpy array

Array with real observations.

fbfloat

Forecast Bias of prediction.

How do we interpret forecast bias? Here are two important properties:

  • Large positive value means that our observations are usually higher than prediction. Our model underestimates predictions.

  • Large negative value tells us that our predictions are usually higher than expected values. Our model overestimates predictions.

Equation:

  1. $$e_{fb} =

rac{sum_{i}^{N}{y_{i} - ar{y_{i}}}}{N}$$

where: * $e_{fb}$ - forecast bias, * $y_{i}$ - i-th observation, * $ar{y_{i}}$ - i-th prediction, * $N$ - number of observations.

mean_absolute_error(predicted_array: array, real_array: array) → float[source]#

Function calculates forecast bias of prediction.

predicted_arraynumpy array

Array with predicted values.

real_arraynumpy array

Array with real observations.

fbfloat

Forecast Bias of prediction.

MAE is not the same as RMSE. It is a good idea to compare the mean absolute error with the root mean squared error. We can get information about predictions that are very poor. RMSE that is larger than the MAE is a sign that for some lags our predictions are very poor. We should check those lags.

Equation:

  1. $$e_{mae} =

rac{sum_{i}^{N}{|y_{i} - ar{y_{i}}|}}{N}$$

where: * $e_{mae}$ - mean absolute error, * $y_{i}$ - i-th observation, * $ar{y_{i}}$ - i-th prediction, * $N$ - number of observations.

root_mean_squared_error(predicted_array: array, real_array: array) → float[source]#
predicted_arraynumpy array

Array with predicted values.

real_arraynumpy array

Array with real observations.

rmsefloat

Root Mean Squared Error of prediction.

Important hint: it is a good idea to compare the mean absolute error with the root mean squared error. We can get information about predictions that are very poor. RMSE that is larger than the MAE is a sign that for some lags our predictions are very poor. We should check those lags.

Equation:

  1. e_{rmse} = sqrt{

rac{sum_{i}^{N}({y_{i} - ar{y_{i}})^2}}{N}}$$

where: * $e_{rmse}$ - root mean squared error, * $y_{i}$ - i-th observation, * $ar{y_{i}}$ - i-th prediction, * $N$ - number of observations.

symmetric_mean_absolute_percentage_error(predicted_array: array, real_array: array, test_undefined=True) → float[source]#
predicted_arraynumpy array

Array with predicted values.

real_arraynumpy array

Array with real observations.

test_undefinedbool

Check if there are cases when prediction and observation are equal to 0.

smapefloat

Symmetric Mean Absolute Percentage Error.

UndefinedSMAPEWarning

Observation and prediction are equal to 0 - smape of this pair is undefined and numpy return the NaN value.

Symmetric Mean Absolute Percentage Error is an accuracy measure that returns error in percent. It is a relative evaluation metrics. It shouldn’t be used alone because it can return different values for overforecast and underforecast. The SMAPE penalizes more underforecasting, thus it should be compared to Forecast Bias to have a full view of the model properties. SMAPE is better than RMSE or FB because it is better suited to compare multiple models with different number of parameteres, for example, number of ranges.

More about SMAPE here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_mean_absolute_percentage_error

Equation:

  1. $$e_{smape} =

rac{100}{N} sum_{i}^{N}{ rac{|ar{y_{i}} - y_{i}|}{|y_{i}|+|ar{y_{i}}|}}$$

where: * $e_{smape}$ - symmetric mean absolute percentage error, * $y_{i}$ - i-th observation, * $ar{y_{i}}$ - i-th prediction, * $N$ - number of observations.

weighted_root_mean_squared_error(predicted_array: array, real_array: array, weighting_method: str, lag_points_distribution=None) → float[source]#
predicted_arraynumpy array

Array with predicted values.

real_arraynumpy array

Array with real observations.

weighting_methodstr

The name of a method used to weight error at a given lags. Available methods: - closest: lags at a close range have larger weights, - distant: lags that are further away have larger weights, - dense: error is weighted by the number of point pairs within a lag.

lag_points_distributionnumpy array

Array with points per lag (real observations).

wrmsefloat

Weighted Root Mean Squared Error of prediction.

AttributeError : The lag_points_distribution parameter is undefined when “dense” method is selected.

Error weighting is a useful method in the case when we want to force variogram to better represent semivariances at specific ranges. The most popular is “closest” - we create model that fits better pairs near the origin.

Equations:

  • “closest”

  1. $$e_{wrmse} = sqrt{

rac{sum_{i}^{N}({y_{i} - ar{y_{i}})^2}* rac{N-i}{N}}{N}}$$

where: * $e_{rmse}$ - weighted root mean squared error, * $i$ - lag, i > 0, * $y_{i}$ - i-th observation, * $ar{y_{i}}$ - i-th prediction, * $N$ - number of observations.

  • “distant”

  1. $$e_{wrmse} = sqrt{

rac{sum_{i}^{N}({y_{i} - ar{y_{i}})^2}* rac{i}{N}}{N}}$$

where: * $e_{rmse}$ - weighted root mean squared error, * $i$ - lag, i > 0, * $y_{i}$ - i-th observation, * $ar{y_{i}}$ - i-th prediction, * $N$ - number of observations.

  • “dense”

  1. $$e_{wrmse} = sqrt{

rac{sum_{i}^{N}({y_{i} - ar{y_{i}})^2}* rac{p_{i}}{P}}{N}}$$

where: * $e_{rmse}$ - weighted root mean squared error, * $y_{i}$ - i-th observation, * $ar{y_{i}}$ - i-th prediction, * $p_{i}$ - number of points within i-th lag, * $P$ - number of all points, * $N$ - number of observations.
